occurrences.line_text: Vnto the barre, whereas she was arrayned:
Which was, that through this worlds wyde wildernes
And now she was vppon the weary way,
Her tyreling iade, was bent her to abuse;
For he was sterne, and terrible by nature,
For sooth he was descended of the hous
And sib to great Orgolio, which was slaine
Vpon checklaton he was straungely dight,
This was Disdaine, who led that Ladies horse
Was Scorne, who hauing in his hand a whip,
And saw him selfe captiu'd, he was dismayd,
Was much more grieuous, then the others blowes:
That slaine he was, or made a wretched thrall,
Ere she againe to Calepine was brought;
Was touched with compassion entire,
(That was that courteous Knight, whom he before
Was much asham'd, that with an hempen cord
He like a dog was led in captiue case,
His manly mynde was much emmoued therewithall.
Whose doome was death, but lightly slipping by,
For as his hand was heaued vp on hight,
He driuen was to ground in selfe despight;
But yet the Prince so well enured was
And smote him on the knee, that neuer yet was bent.
It neuer yet was bent, ne bent it now,
So as it was vnable to support
I was belou'd of many a gentle Knight,
Who was not able vp him selfe to reare,
Was crackt in twaine, but by his foolish feere
Was holpen vp, who him supported standing neare.
Who was so far from being ought amazed,
It was his owne true groome, the gentle Squire,
Then he was tride vnto his Lady bright:
The best aduizement was of bad, to let her
That since by grace of God she there was sent,
By this dispred, that was the tyme ordayned
The Damzell was before the altar set,
Ne ought was tyred with his endlesse toyles,
Ne ought was feared of his certaine harmes:
In which his loue was lost, he slept full fast,
Of all, which there was doing in that quire:
The knight was nothing nice, where was no need,
The knight was nothing nice, where was no need,
Vpon a litle hillocke she was placed
And soothly sure she was full fayre of face,
Ne was there heard, ne was there shepheards swayne
Ne was there heard, ne was there shepheards swayne
He was vnwares surprisd in subtile bands
Was farre forth spent, discoursing diuersly
He was to weet by common voice esteemed
Yet was not so, but as old stories tell
That she in tract of time accompted was his owne.
There he was welcom'd of that honest syre,
The time was once, in my first prime of yeares,
That he was rapt with double rauishment,
On which his hungry eye was alwayes bent;
What time the golden apple was vnto him brought.
He much was troubled at that straungers guize,
Where Calidore was present, he would loure,
Was readie oft his owne hart to deuoure,
That he should lead the daunce, as was his fashion;
A garland was the meed of victory.
Therein well practisd was, and in the same
For he was strong and mightily stiffe pight,
Then was the oaken crowne by Pastorell
Was fauoured, and to her grace commmended.
Which by the Faery Queene was on him layd,
Whilest his faire Pastorella was elsewhere,
For all that euer was by natures skill
Deuized to worke delight, was gathered there,
It was an hill plaste in an open plaine,
That round about was bordered with a wood
Therefore it rightly cleeped was mount Acidale.
And in the middest of those same three, was placed
Such was the beauty of this goodly band,
That in the midst was placed parauaunt,
Was she to whom that shepheard pypt alone,
She was to weete that iolly Shepheards lasse,
That iolly shepheard, which there piped, was
Therefore resoluing, what it was, to know,
But what so sure she was, she worthy was,
But what so sure she was, she worthy was,
Yet was she certes but a countrey lasse,
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
Was hunting in the woods (as was his trade)
Was hunting in the woods (as was his trade)
Mongst which this lucklesse mayd away was lad,
Which was the conquest of the gentlest Knight,
With them also was taken Coridon,
Their dwelling in a little Island was,
For vnderneath the ground their way was made,
Ne lightned was with window, nor with louer,
Into this place was brought, and kept with gard
That he, which was their Capitaine profest,
At sight whereof his barbarous heart was fired,
Sith in his powre she was to foe or frend;
That further, then she willing was, he prest;
Her sickenesse was not of the body but the mynde.
Were brought vnto their Captaine, who was set
Then forth the good old Meliboe was brought,
Was his owne purchase and his onely prize,
So shew'd them her, to proue how pale & weake she was.
Such was the conflict of those cruell Brigants there.
Was by the Captaine all this while defended:
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
Tho when as he was dead, the fray gan ceasse,
Her louely light was dimmed and decayd,
And his owne flesh he readie was to teare:
That Coridon it was, the silly shepherds hynd.
And gushing forth in teares, was so opprest,
Where was his Pastorell? where all the other crew?
This dismall day, and was not dead before,
To marchants, but was sau'd with strong defence?
His hart quite deaded was with anguish great,
When she was slaine, or had bene to her succour nere.
But he, whose hart through feare was late fordonne,
Was almost dead, misdoubting least of new
But when as Calidore was comen in,
She sudden was reuiued therewithall,
The hue and cry was raysed all about;
Of that was doen, and entred in a rout.
So long till all the entry was with bodies mand.
Whilst none was him to stop, nor none him to restraine.
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
Who whylome was in his youthes freshest flowre
Her name was Claribell: whose father hight
That of her loue he was entyrely seized,
Whereof her wombe vnwist to wight was fraught,
Was dighting her, hauing her snowy brest
Was that same infant, which so long sith past
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
And what the matter was, that mou'd her so.
Much was the Lady troubled at that speach,
As Pastorella was, that nigh she swelt
And to the Clergy now was come at last;
Did cast to ground, whilest none was them to rew;
Such was the fury of this hellish Beast,
To griesly Pluto, what on earth was donne,
Him liberty was left aloud to rore:
Thus was this Monster by the maystring might
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
In wine and oyle they wash his woundes wide,
And Gehons golden waues doe wash continually.
The filthy blots of sinne to wash away.
And wash thy hands from guilt of bloudy field:
And guilt of sinfull crimes cleane wash away,
And faynd to wash themselues incessantly;
To spin, to card, to sew, to wash, to wring;
And with her teares his wounds did wash and steepe.
His bloudy vessels wash, and holy fire prepare.
And washed all her place with watry eyen.
Of wealthy Thamis washed is along,
And washeth Winborne meades in season drye.
Washing his bloudy wounds, that through the steele were cleft.
For all his washing cleaner. Still he stroue,
Some of them washing with the liquid dew
Him follow'd Yar, soft washing Norwitch wall,
Whose false foundation waues haue washt away,
He washt them oft and oft, yet nought they beene
And washt away his guilt with guiltie potion.
That all the bloud and filth away was washt,
The whiles my hands I washt in puritie,
Are washt away quite from their memorie.
And washt the same with water, which did well
Her siluer feet, faire washt against this day:
But the streame washt away her guilty blood.
The most part of my land hath washt away,
Her hands were foule and durtie, neuer washt
So well she washt them, and so well she watcht him,
An angry Waspe th'one in a viall had
The griesly Wasserman, that makes his game
But his wast wordes returnd to him in vaine:
Lets me not sleepe, but wast the wearie night
And wast his inward gall with deepe despight,
Which wast begot in Dï¿½mogorgons hall,
And with an yuie twyne his wast is girt about.
Then serue his Ladies loue, and wast in pleasures vayne.
And made wide shadow vnder his huge wast;
And wast thy ioyous houres in needlesse paine,
And suffred rash Pyrrochles wast his idle might.
But all the liquour, which was fowle and wast,
Like loathly Toades, some fashioned in the wast
Surfeat, misdiet, and vnthriftie wast,
Of lustfull luxurie and thriftlesse wast:
And brought to ground, that neuer wast before;
Her wretched dayes in dolour she mote wast,
Was neuer so great wast in any place,
Which wast begot in heauen, but for thy bad
And in lewd slouth to wast his carelesse day:
His inward parts, and all his entrayles wast,
About her sclender wast, he tooke in hand,
But all my dayes am like to wast in vaine,
But wholy wast, and void of peoples trode,
Wast there enwouen, and the sad distresse,
And her small wast girt round with yron bands,
With darknes dred, and threatens all the world to wast.
That none durst euer whilest thou wast aliue,
Ne felt his blood to wast, ne powres emperisht,
Full oft about her wast she it enclos'd;
And it as oft was from about her wast disclos'd.
His wast was with a wreath of yuie greene
And wast his wretched daies in wofull plight;
The more his weakened body so to wast:
Was spoyle to make, and wast them vnto nought,
I wast my life, and doe my daies deuowre
Her selfe then tooke he by the sclender wast,
But th'emptie girdle, which about her wast was wrought.
Who round about her tender wast it fitted well.
Such power it had, that to no womans wast
And his abridged dayes in dolour wast,
And had three bodies in one wast empight,
Then here to see all desolate and wast,
Then brought she me into this desert waste,
Banisht from liuing wights, our wearie dayes we waste.
Where she did wander in waste wildernesse,
Does waste his dayes in darke obscuritee,
And come vnto an Island, waste and voyd,
Through countries waste, and eke well edifyde,
But that she still did waste, and still did wayle,
Then waste in woe and wailefull miserie.
Laught at his foolish labour spent in waste;
Her tender waste was wound, adowne gan fall,
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
And raught downe to his waste, when vp he stood,
Vnto her waste, with flowres bescattered,
But let me waste in woe my wretched yeares,
To weary him the more, and waste his spight,
And waste her goodly beauty, which did fade
The playnes all waste and emptie did appeare:
Haue wasted, louing him with all my powre,
Through wicked pride, and wasted wealthes decay.
Their kingdome spoild, and countrey wasted quight:
Where he his better dayes hath wasted all.
Tho when her well of teares she wasted had,
And wasted life do lye in ashes low.
They wasted had much way, and measurd many miles.
And more had wasted, could no whit dismay;
Yet still he wasted, as the snow congealed,
He was so wasted and forpined quight,
Seeing his worke now wasted deepe engrieued was.
Latonaes childrens wrath, that all her issue wasted.
Long so they trauelled through wastefull wayes,
Shortly vnto the wastefull woods she came,
That yonder in that wastefull wildernesse
Nor wight appear'd, but wastefull emptinesse,
Where she in darknes wastes her cursed daies & nights.
In languor wastes his life:
That wasteth all this countrey farre and neare.
Far hence (quoth he) in wastfull wildernesse
In wildernesse and wastfull deserts strayd,
Through wastfull Pride, and wanton Riotise,
Fled to the wastfull wildernesse apace,
For still he traueild through wide wastfull ground,
Which still sate waiting on that wastfull clift,
But feard to wander in that wastfull mist,
But in lewd loues, and wastfull luxuree,
Banisht from Princely bowre to wastfull wood:
Through the wide region of the wastfull aire,
That with the wasting of his vitall flood,
Wasting the strength of her immortall age.
Wasting her goodly hew in heauie teares,
Through woods and wastnesse wide him daily sought;
Still when she slept, he kept both watch and ward,
And at her feet the Lyon watch doth keepe:
Still did he wake, and still did watch for dawning light.
And watch the noyous night, and wait for ioyous day.
And with continuall watch did warely keepe;
Day and night keeping wary watch and ward,
And euer as he went, dew watch vpon him kept.
They for vs fight, they watch and dewly ward,
Against his foe and mine: watch thou I pray;
And wisely watch to ward that deadly stowre:
The watch, and lowd vnto the knights did call,
Day and night duely keeping watch and ward,
Where through long watch, & late dayes weary toile,
Kept watch and ward about her warily,
And set her by to watch, and set her by to weepe.
That weenes with watch and hard restraint to stay
Vnto their wils, and one eyes watch escape;
Two eyes him needeth, for to watch and wake,
But Paridell kept better watch, then hee,
Vaine was the watch, and bootlesse all the ward,
Then when the second watch was almost past,
Whom when the watch, that kept continuall ward
Who day and night did watch and duely ward,
To keepe a nightly watch, for dread of treachery.
Ye will not watch? false watches, wellaway,
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
Thus did she watch, and weare the weary night
Vppon their wall good watch and ward did keepe.
He gan to watch the wielding of his hand,
And watch aduauntage, how to worke his care:
But by her wounded loue did watch all night,
And wary watch about her for her safegard keepe.
Or who did wayle or watch the wearie night?
And kept them with continuall watch and ward,
But her all night did watch, and all the day molest.
Vnwont with heards to watch, or pasture sheepe,
For it was warely watched night and day,
Whiles Talus watched at the dore all night.
And wakefull watches euer to abide:
Two goodly Beacons, set in watches stead,
Ye will not watch? false watches, wellaway,
Their watchet mantles frindgd with siluer round,
All decked in a robe of watchet hew,
Yet warily he watcheth euery way,
The souldier may not moue from watchfull sted,
But they were both so watchfull and well eyde,
Called aloud vnto the watchfull ward,
Thus she all night wore out in watchfulnesse,
Watching to banish Care their enimy,
So th'euill thinkes by watching to preuent;
Watching to driue the rauenous Wolfe away,
The watchman wayting tydings glad to heare,
Vnto the watchman on the castle wall;
Where they arriuing, by the watchmen were
All night she watcht, ne once adowne would lay
And watcht, that none should enter nor issew;
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
His eye-lids sad, but watcht continually,
With Belge, who watcht all this while full sad,
So well she washt them, and so well she watcht him,
He watcht in close awayt with weapons prest,
Were hidd in water, that I could not see,
That on her shoulders sad a pot of water bore.
And fifty sisters water in leake vessels draw.
Forth gushed, like fresh water streame from riuen rocke.
With wine and water fild vp to the hight,
His bodie in salt water smarting sore,
Were hardned with that holy water dew,
And holy water thereon sprinckled wide;
Downe to that well, did in the water weene
Might not be purgd with water nor with bath;
And yet her vertues in her water byde:
May not be clensd with water of this well:
Or to behold the water worke, and play
Will die for thirst, and water doth refuse?
Yet still he bet the water, and the billowes dasht.
Aboue the water were on high extent,
Like a great water flood, that tombling low
That quicksand nigh with water couered;
Ne doe they need with water of the ford,
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
Is this, then that same water of Ardenne,
Of muddie water, that like puddle stanke;
Then running water, tempred with his teares,
And washt the same with water, which did well
And water all the English soile throughout;
Is cal'de Blacke water, and the Liffar deep,
And wau'd vpon, like water Chamelot,
Ne ought the water cooled their whot bloud,
To fight in water, great aduantage had,
And durst the depth of any water sownd.
But from the water to the land betooke his flight.
But bread and water, or like feeble thing,
Like as a water streame, whose swelling sourse
And dry vp all the water, which doth ronne
Yet were her words but wynd, & all her teares but water.
Like many water streames, a while she stayd;
By sweet Clonmell, adornes rich Waterford;
The streame thereof would driue a water-mill.
And through the world of waters wide and deepe,
And bad the waters, which from her did flow,
Thenceforth her waters waxed dull and slow,
Had vertue pourd into their waters bace,
What colour were their waters that same day,
That the hoare waters from his frigot ran,
In the wide waters: therefore are they hight
Whose circled waters rapt with whirling sway,
The surging waters like a mountaine rise,
Aboue the waters, and then downe againe
Birdes, voyces, instruments, windes, waters, all agree.
With the base murmure of the waters fall:
The waters fall with difference discreet,
His mightie waters to them buxome bee;
And the great waters gin apace to swell,
His borrowed waters forst to redisbourse,
The which Pactolus with his waters shere,
Else would the waters ouerflow the lands,
The waters play and pleasant lands appeare,
Eurypulus, that calmes the waters wroth;
The waters depth, and doth their bottome tread;
And the still Darent, in whose waters cleane
And let their swelling waters low before him fall.
Into his waters, as he passeth downe,
The next, the stubborne Newre, whose waters gray
And all mankinde do nourish with their waters clere.
In swimming be expert through waters force to pas.
Whose waters with his filthy bloud it stayned:
Hemd in with waters like a wall in sight;
In the woods shade, which did the waters crowne,
And to the waters fall tuning their accents fit.
As fast as water-sprinckles gainst a rocke are dasht.
So went he playing on the watery plaine.
And his faint steedes watred in Ocean deepe,
His ship farre come from watrie wildernesse,
Whom whylest she did with watrie eyne behold,
And washed all her place with watry eyen.
With hart then throbbing, and with watry eyes,
But with his oares did sweepe the watry wildernesse.
For which he faded to a watry flowre.
The watry Southwinde from the seabord cost
Amongst her watry sisters by a pond,
And to her watry chamber swiftly carry him.
His watry eyes, drizling like deawy raine,
Foolish Narcisse, that likes the watry shore,
Doe meete together on the watry lea,
A watry cloud doth ouercast the skie,
To that great banquet of the watry Gods,
But leauing watry gods, as booting nought,
Hath in a watry cloud displayed wide
And wau'd vpon, like water Chamelot,
With tinsell trappings, wouen like a waue,
Whose bubbling waue did euer freshly well,
That makes fraile flesh to feare the bitter waue?
In all his wayes through this wide worldes waue,
As Eagle fresh out of the Ocean waue,
And with her brest breaking the fomy waue,
Vpon the trembling waue, so shined bright,
A gentle streame, whose murmuring waue did play
It cut away vpon the yielding waue,
The slouthfull waue of that great griesly lake;
Whiles thus they strugled in that idle waue,
As Pilot well expert in perilous waue,
And with vncomely weedes the gentle waue accloyes.
And seuen times dipped in the bitter waue
And all his senses drowned in deepe senselesse waue.
The hollow vessell through the threatfull waue,
But by the checked waue they did descry
That with the angry working of the waue,
They waued like a penon wide dispred,
Perceiued him to wauer weake and fraile,
And into diuerse doubt his wauering wonder cloue.
Out of his wauering seat him pluckt perforse,
In wauering wemens wit, that none can tell,
Was alwaies flitting as the wauering wind,
Of doubtfull fortune wauering to and fro,
His wauering mind, yet to his aide agreed,
Her wauering lust after her wandring sight,
His fattie waues do fertile slime outwell,
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waues emong.
That was in Ocean waues yet neuer wet,
They pas the bitter waues of Acheron,
In westerne waues his wearie wagon did recure.
And Gehons golden waues doe wash continually.
Defyld those sacred waues, it rightly hot
Whose false foundation waues haue washt away,
And the cleane waues with purple gore did ray;
Ne lets her waues with any filth be dyde,
In woods, in waues, in warres she wonts to dwell,
Thus in still waues of deepe delight to wade,
Emongst wide waues set, like a litle nest,
The which on the dull waues did lightly flote
The waues about, and all his armour swept,
The waues thereof so slow and sluggish were,
With liquid waues, fiers Vulcans rage to tame,
In those sad waues, which direfull deadly stanke,
Amid the Ocean waues, ne was it sought
Vpon the waues to spred her trembling light,
Ouer the waues his rugged armes doth lift,
The waues come rolling, and the billowes rore
Came rushing in the fomy waues enrold,
And on the rocke the waues breaking aloft,
That seemd the waues were into yuory,
Or yuory into the waues were sent;
That through the waues one might the bottom see,
So through the Christall waues appeared plaine:
So hid in lockes and waues from lookers theft,
Which sparckling on the silent waues, does seeme more bright.
Eftsoones his heaped waues he did commaund,
The waues obedient to their beheast,
As swift as swallowes, on the waues they went,
And through the brackish waues their passage sheare;
Did heape on her new waues of weary wretchednesse.
Along the fomy waues driuing his finny droue.
Was drawne vpon the waues, that fomed him around.
So drag'd him through the waues in scornefull state,
Raging within the waues: thereby he weend
It Troynouant is hight, that with the waues
Into huge waues of griefe and gealosye
That made the sparckling waues to smoke agayne,
For wall'd it was with waues, which rag'd and ror'd
The powre to rule the billowes, and the waues to tame.
On which the waues, glittering like Christall glas,
And Bristow faire, which on his waues he builded hath.
And Mulla mine, whose waues I whilom taught to weep.
What though the sea with waues continuall
Whether by rage of waues, that neuer rest,
And wading through the waues with stedfast sway,
A Ladie on rough waues, row'd in a sommer barge.
And strongly wading through the waues vnused,
His siluer waues did softly tumble downe,
Then with his wauing wings displayed wyde,
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
And wearie waxe of his continuall stay.
Thenceforth her waters waxed dull and slow,
Eftsoones long waxen torches weren light,
Led with delight, they thus beguile the way,
And creeping sought way in the weedy gras:
So forward on his way (with God to frend)
